unnormalised: Planning a trip on the Indian Railways? It’s still one of the best ways to see the country, especially if you’re not in a rush. But navigating the system can be a bit… interesting. Let’s talk about it, shall we? Forget booking in advance; you'll be waiting till the cows come home. Try booking a few weeks out - say, 30 days-ish, maybe a bit more if it’s a holiday time.

Let's talk about it, shall we? Forget booking in advance; you'll be waiting till the cows come home. Try booking a few weeks out - say, thirty days-ish, maybe a bit more if it's a holiday time.

unnormalised: First off, let's discuss tickets. IRCTC's website can be your best friend or your worst enemy. Be ready for slow loading times, especially around 10:00 AM when Tatkal bookings open. And don't be surprised if your payment fails a few times. It happens! Pro tip: keep refreshing. Also keep your PNR no. handy once you book those tickets – you'll need it.

And don't be surprised if your payment fails a few times. It happens! Pro tip: keep refreshing. Also keep your P-N-R number handy once you book those tickets – you'll need it.

unnormalised: Then there's the train types. From the super-fast Rajdhani to the good old passenger trains, there's a service for every budget and timeframe. The 12002 Bhopal Shatabdi is a personal favourite for a quick Delhi-Agra jaunt. And don't forget those long-distance journeys on the Howrah Mail – truly epic! Plus, you'll get to try all the platform delicacies you can.

unnormalised: Now, a word about train etiquette. Sharing chai with your fellow passengers is practically mandatory. Offering your upper berth to an elderly traveller is a guaranteed way to earn good karma. And please, try to keep the noise down after 10 PM, especially if you're in a sleeper class. A lot of people are trying to catch some zzz’s!

unnormalised: Food-wise, the options range from decent to questionable. Pack some snacks, just in case. Maggi and bread are always a safe bet! Don't forget to check your train timings – like train no. 12623 – on NTES. It’ll save you from missing your train (speaking from experience, LOL!).

unnormalised: So, there you have it – a quick and dirty guide to travelling on the Indian Railways. Embrace the chaos, enjoy the scenery, and remember to keep a sense of humour.
